trips.title: Garth Mountain
trips.transport: 30 minute drive to Gwaelod-y-Garth. Transport is arranged for you. Return to Cardiff Central by 4pm.
trips.description: We start from the village, up through evergreen forest, then out onto open hillside. Depending on the season and weather, you will see cows grazing, sheep having a sunbath, crows chilling on the grass. Keep an eye out for mushrooms on the forest floor. At the top are four Bronze Age burial mounds that have stood here for 4000 years, and panoramic views over Taffs Well, the river Taff, Cardiff with its iconic landmarks, and Somerset in the distance. We head back down a different route to the Gwaelod y Garth Inn, a 19th century pub with flagstone floors and open fires. Finish your day with a Baileys shot or a hot cocoa and each other's company.
trips.routeDescription: 5km loop with about 250m of climbing to the summit at 307m.

itinerary.description: Meet at Mackintosh Sport club. We recommend arriving half an hour early as Roath Market happens here every week. Lots of local products, good coffee, and food to take with you for the day.
Drive to Gwaelod-y-Garth village (30 mins)
Start walking up through the pine forest
Reach the top, lunch break with views
Head down the north side to Gwaelod y Garth Inn
Return to Cardiff Central

wear: Trainers with good grip or walking shoes (path can be muddy after rain)

faq.question: How steep is it?
faq.answer: Some sections are steep but nothing technical. Take your time and we'll wait for everyone.

trips.selfDirected: Want to do this walk on your own? Transport can be a little tricky because there is no direct bus or train to Gwaelod-y-Garth. Your best bet is the train from Cathays to Pontypridd, get off at Taffs Well, then it's about a 10 min walk to the start of the route.

trips.title: Castell Coch
trips.meeting: Taffs Well station car park, 11am. Pickup from Cardiff Central at 10:45am if needed.
trips.transport: Train from Central 15 mins (about £4 return) or pickup available. Back by 3pm.
trips.notes: Castle entry optional (£8 Cadw, members free). Victorian Gothic revival, interiors worth seeing.
wear: Trainers fine, paths are well maintained
trips.description: We catch the train to Taffs Well and walk from there through Fforest Fawr, old woodland with big oaks and beech trees. The path climbs at the end to Castell Coch, a Victorian Gothic castle with painted ceilings and a working drawbridge. We have lunch at the castle café, then head back the same way.
trips.routeDescription: Easy woodland walk through Fforest Fawr to Castell Coch. Well-maintained paths. 5km, 2 hours.

itinerary.description: Optional pickup from Cardiff Central
Meet at Taffs Well station car park
Start walking through Fforest Fawr woodland
Arrive at Castell Coch
Lunch at castle café (or bring your own)
Optional castle tour (£8 entry)
Walk back through the woods
Return to Taffs Well / Cardiff Central

bring: Packed lunch or money for café

faq.question: Do I need to pay to enter the castle?
faq.answer: Entry is optional. It's £8 for adults (Cadw members free). The grounds and café are free to access.

faq.question: Is this suitable for children?
faq.answer: Yes, the walk is easy and kids love the castle. The drawbridge and towers are a highlight.

trips.title: Pontneddfechan Waterfalls
trips.meeting: Cardiff Central station, by the taxi rank, 9am
trips.transport: 1 hour drive to Pontneddfechan, Brecon Beacons. Pub stop in Merthyr on the way back. In Cardiff by 4:30pm.
trips.description: We drive an hour into the Brecon Beacons and follow the rivers Mellte and Hepste through sandstone gorges, passing four waterfalls. The main one is Sgwd yr Eira ('Waterfall of Snow'). 170 steps down, then we walk behind the 30ft cascade on an old sheep farmers' path. Pub lunch in Merthyr on the way back.
trips.routeDescription: Four Waterfalls Trail. 8km, 3-4 hours. Rocky sections, steep steps. Walk behind Sgwd yr Eira.

itinerary.description: Meet at Cardiff Central station, by the taxi rank
Drive to Pontneddfechan (1 hour)
Start walking the Four Waterfalls Trail
Sgwd Clun-Gwyn (first waterfall)
Sgwd yr Eira, walk behind the waterfall
Lunch break by the river
Return to car park
Drive to Merthyr, pub stop
Return to Cardiff Central

faq.question: How difficult is the walk?
faq.answer: Moderate. There are 170 steps down to one waterfall and the path is rocky in places. Walking boots essential.

faq.question: Can we actually walk behind the waterfall?
faq.answer: Yes, there's an old sheep farmers' path that goes behind Sgwd yr Eira. You might get a bit of spray.

faq.question: What if it's been raining?
faq.answer: The waterfalls are even more impressive after rain. The paths can be slippery though, so take care.

trips.title: Pen-y-Fan
trips.meeting: Cardiff Central station, by the taxi rank, 8am
trips.transport: Mini-bus to Storey Arms car park (50 mins each way). Back in Cardiff by 4:30pm.
wear: Walking boots with good ankle support
Spare warm layer in case of cold
Microspikes if you have them (ice possible)
trips.description: We take the mini-bus up to Storey Arms, the traditional starting point for Pen-y-Fan. The path climbs steadily from the car park, steep in places, with the summit at 886m (the highest point in southern Britain). On a clear day you can see the Bristol Channel, the Black Mountains, and across to the Preseli Hills in Pembrokeshire. From the top we head west to Corn Du, then drop down toward the Upper Neuadd Reservoir before looping back along an old drovers' road. In winter the ground can be frozen or boggy, and the summit is often in cloud or wind. We go at the group's pace and turn back if conditions are poor.
trips.routeDescription: Circular via Pen-y-Fan (886m) and Corn Du. 11km, 4-5 hours. Steep ascent from Storey Arms, exposed summit ridge, reservoir return.

itinerary.description: Meet at Cardiff Central station, by the taxi rank
Depart by mini-bus to Storey Arms (50 mins)
Arrive Storey Arms, kit check and set off
Summit Pen-y-Fan (886m)
Continue to Corn Du, then descend toward reservoir
Lunch break by Upper Neuadd Reservoir
Return via drovers' road to Storey Arms
Back at mini-bus, depart for Cardiff
Return to Cardiff Central

bring: Packed lunch and snacks (nothing available on route)

faq.question: What if there's snow or ice?
faq.answer: We'll assess conditions on the day. If there's significant ice on the path, microspikes help. If it's unsafe, we'll shorten the route or reschedule.

faq.question: How cold will it be?
faq.answer: At 886m in February, expect temperatures around freezing or below, with wind chill making it feel colder. Dress in layers and bring a hat and gloves.

faq.question: Is this harder than the other trips?
faq.answer: Yes. The ascent is steep, the summit is exposed, and winter conditions add difficulty. You should be comfortable walking uphill for an hour or more.

faq.question: Can we stop if the weather turns?
faq.answer: Absolutely. We can turn back at any point. The summit ridge is exposed, so if visibility drops or wind picks up, we'll descend.

faq.title: Frequently Asked Questions
faq.description: Common questions about how trips work.

items.question: What if I need to cancel?
items.answer: Let us know at least 48 hours before and we'll refund your fee. Last-minute cancellations can't be refunded as we may have turned others away.

items.question: Do I need to bring my own equipment?
items.answer: Just what's listed on each trip — usually lunch, water, and appropriate footwear. We don't do anything requiring specialist gear.

items.question: How do I pay?
items.answer: Bank transfer or WeChat Pay before the trip. Details sent when you book.

items.question: What happens if the weather is bad?
items.answer: We go ahead in light rain — it's Wales. If conditions are unsafe, we'll reschedule or refund. We'll message the group the evening before if there's any doubt.
